column2: Chapter 22.
column3: Chapter twenty two.

column2: The Opening of the Flower
column3: The Opening of the Flower

column2: The night passed away very sweetly for Cornelius, although in great agitation.
column3: The night passed away very sweetly for Cornelius, although in great agitation.

column2: Every instant he fancied he heard the gentle voice of Rosa calling him.
column3: Every instant he fancied he heard the gentle voice of Rosa calling him.

column2: He then started up, went to the door, and looked through the grating, but no one was behind it, and the lobby was empty.
column3: He then started up, went to the door, and looked through the grating, but no one was behind it, and the lobby was empty.

column2: Rosa, no doubt, would be watching too, but, happier than he, she watched over the tulip; she had before her eyes that noble flower, that wonder of wonders, which not only was unknown, but was not even thought possible until then.
column3: Rosa, no doubt, would be watching too, but, happier than he, she watched over the tulip; she had before her eyes that noble flower, that wonder of wonders, which not only was unknown, but was not even thought possible until then.

column2: What would the world say when it heard that the black tulip was found, that it existed and that it was the prisoner Van Baerle who had found it?
column3: What would the world say when it heard that the black tulip was found, that it existed and that it was the prisoner Van Baerle who had found it?

column2: How Cornelius would have spurned the offer of his liberty in exchange for his tulip!
column3: How Cornelius would have spurned the offer of his liberty in exchange for his tulip!

column2: Day came, without any news; the tulip was not yet in flower.
column3: Day came, without any news; the tulip was not yet in flower.

column2: The day passed as the night.
column3: The day passed as the night.

column2: Night came, and with it Rosa, joyous and cheerful as a bird.
column3: Night came, and with it Rosa, joyous and cheerful as a bird.

column2: Well? asked Cornelius.
column3: Well? asked Cornelius.

column2: Well, all is going on prosperously.	Well, all is going on prosperously.
column3: true

column2: This night, without any doubt, our tulip will be in flower."
column3: This night, without any doubt, our tulip will be in flower."

column2: And will it flower black?
column3: And will it flower black?

column2: Black as jet.
column3: Black as jet.

column2: Without a speck of any other colour.
column3: Without a speck of any other colour.

column2: Without one speck.
column3: Without one speck.

column2: Good Heavens! my dear Rosa, I have been dreaming all night, in the first place of you, (Rosa made a sign of incredulity,) "and then of what we must do."
column3: Good Heavens! my dear Rosa, I have been dreaming all night, in the first place of you, (Rosa made a sign of incredulity,) "and then of what we must do."

column2: Well?
column3: Well?

column2: Well, and I will tell you now what I have decided on.	Well, and I will tell you now what I have decided on.
column3: true

column2: The tulip once being in flower, and it being quite certain that it is perfectly black, you must find a messenger."
column3: The tulip once being in flower, and it being quite certain that it is perfectly black, you must find a messenger."

column2: If it is no more than that, I have a messenger quite ready.
column3: If it is no more than that, I have a messenger quite ready.

column2: Is he safe?
column3: Is he safe?

column2: One for whom I will answer,--he is one of my lovers.
column3: One for whom I will answer,--he is one of my lovers.

column2: I hope not Jacob.
column3: I hope not Jacob.

column2: No, be quiet, it is the ferryman of Loewestein, a smart young man of twenty-five.
column3: No, be quiet, it is the ferryman of Loewestein, a smart young man of twenty five.

column2: By Jove!
column3: By Jove!

column2: Be quiet, said Rosa, smiling, "he is still under age, as you have yourself fixed it from twenty-six to twenty-eight."
column3: Be quiet, said Rosa, smiling, "he is still under age, as you have yourself fixed it from twenty six to twenty eight."

column2: In fine, do you think you may rely on this young man?
column3: In fine, do you think you may rely on this young man?

column2: As on myself; he would throw himself into the Waal or the Meuse if I bade him.
column3: As on myself; he would throw himself into the Waal or the Meuse if I bade him.

column2: Well, Rosa, this lad may be at Haarlem in ten hours; you will give me paper and pencil, and, perhaps better still, pen and ink, and I will write, or rather, on second thoughts, you will, for if I did, being a poor prisoner, people might, like your father, see a conspiracy in it. You will write to the President of the Horticultural Society, and I am sure he will come.
column3: Well, Rosa, this lad may be at Haarlem in ten hours; you will give me paper and pencil, and, perhaps better still, pen and ink, and I will write, or rather, on second thoughts, you will, for if I did, being a poor prisoner, people might, like your father, see a conspiracy in it. You will write to the President of the Horticultural Society, and I am sure he will come.

column2: But if he tarries?
column3: But if he tarries?

column2: Well, let us suppose that he tarries one day, or even two; but it is impossible.	Well, let us suppose that he tarries one day, or even two; but it is impossible.
column3: true

column2: A tulip-fancier like him will not tarry one hour, not one minute, not one second, to set out to see the eighth wonder of the world.
column3: A tulip fancier like him will not tarry one hour, not one minute, not one second, to set out to see the eighth wonder of the world.

column2: But, as I said, if he tarried one or even two days, the tulip will still be in its full splendour.
column3: But, as I said, if he tarried one or even two days, the tulip will still be in its full splendour.

column2: The flower once being seen by the President, and the protocol being drawn up, all is in order; you will only keep a duplicate of the protocol, and intrust the tulip to him. Ah! if we had been able to carry it ourselves, Rosa, it would never have left my hands but to pass into yours; but this is a dream, which we must not entertain," continued Cornelius with a sigh, "the eyes of strangers will see it flower to the last.
column3: The flower once being seen by the President, and the protocol being drawn up, all is in order; you will only keep a duplicate of the protocol, and intrust the tulip to him. Ah! if we had been able to carry it ourselves, Rosa, it would never have left my hands but to pass into yours; but this is a dream, which we must not entertain," continued Cornelius with a sigh, "the eyes of strangers will see it flower to the last.

column2: And above all, Rosa, before the President has seen it, let it not be seen by any one.
column3: And above all, Rosa, before the President has seen it, let it not be seen by any one.

column2: Alas! if any one saw the black tulip, it would be stolen."
column3: Alas! if any one saw the black tulip, it would be stolen."

column2: Oh!
column3: Oh!

column2: Did you not tell me yourself of what you apprehended from your lover Jacob?	Did you not tell me yourself of what you apprehended from your lover Jacob?
column3: true

column2: People will steal one guilder, why not a hundred thousand?"
column3: People will steal one guilder, why not a hundred thousand?"

column2: I shall watch; be quiet.
column3: I shall watch; be quiet.

column2: But if it opened whilst you were here?
column3: But if it opened whilst you were here?

column2: The whimsical little thing would indeed be quite capable of playing such a trick, said Rosa.
column3: The whimsical little thing would indeed be quite capable of playing such a trick, said Rosa.

column2: And if on your return you find it open?
column3: And if on your return you find it open?

column2: Well?
column3: Well?

column2: Oh, Rosa, whenever it opens, remember that not a moment must be lost in apprising the President.
column3: Oh, Rosa, whenever it opens, remember that not a moment must be lost in apprising the President.

column2: And in apprising you.	And in apprising you.
column3: true

column2: Yes, I understand."
column3: Yes, I understand."

column2: Rosa sighed, yet without any bitter feeling, but rather like a woman who begins to understand a foible, and to accustom herself to it.
column3: Rosa sighed, yet without any bitter feeling, but rather like a woman who begins to understand a foible, and to accustom herself to it.

column2: I return to your tulip, Mynheer van Baerle, and as soon as it opens I will give you news, which being done the messenger will set out immediately.
column3: I return to your tulip, Mynheer van Baerle, and as soon as it opens I will give you news, which being done the messenger will set out immediately.

column2: Rosa, Rosa, I don't know to what wonder under the sun I shall compare you.
column3: Rosa, Rosa, I don't know to what wonder under the sun I shall compare you.

column2: Compare me to the black tulip, and I promise you I shall feel very much flattered.	Compare me to the black tulip, and I promise you I shall feel very much flattered.
column3: true

column2: Good night, then, till we meet again, Mynheer Cornelius."
column3: Good night, then, till we meet again, Mynheer Cornelius."

column2: Oh, say 'Good night, my friend.'
column3: Oh, say 'Good night, my friend.'

column2: Good night, my friend, said Rosa, a little consoled.
column3: Good night, my friend, said Rosa, a little consoled.

column2: Say, 'My very dear friend.'
column3: Say, 'My very dear friend.'

column2: Oh, my friend--
column3: Oh, my friend-

column2: Very dear friend, I entreat you, say 'very dear,' Rosa, very dear.
column3: Very dear friend, I entreat you, say 'very dear,' Rosa, very dear.

column2: Very dear, yes, very dear, said Rosa, with a beating heart, beyond herself with happiness.
column3: Very dear, yes, very dear, said Rosa, with a beating heart, beyond herself with happiness.

column2: And now that you have said 'very dear,' dear Rosa, say also 'most happy': say 'happier and more blessed than ever man was under the sun.' I only lack one thing, Rosa.
column3: And now that you have said 'very dear,' dear Rosa, say also 'most happy': say 'happier and more blessed than ever man was under the sun' I only lack one thing, Rosa.

column2: And that is?
column3: And that is?

column2: Your cheek,--your fresh cheek, your soft, rosy cheek.	Your cheek,--your fresh cheek, your soft, rosy cheek.
column3: true

column2: Oh, Rosa, give it me of your own free will, and not by chance.
column3: Oh, Rosa, give it me of your own free will, and not by chance.

column2: Ah!"
column3: Ah!"

column2: The prisoner's prayer ended in a sigh of ecstasy; his lips met those of the maiden,--not by chance, nor by stratagem, but as Saint-Preux's was to meet the lips of Julie a hundred years later.
column3: The prisoner's prayer ended in a sigh of ecstasy; his lips met those of the maiden,--not by chance, nor by stratagem, but as Saint Preux's was to meet the lips of Julie a hundred years later.

column2: Rosa made her escape.
column3: Rosa made her escape.

column2: Cornelius stood with his heart upon his lips, and his face glued to the wicket in the door.
column3: Cornelius stood with his heart upon his lips, and his face glued to the wicket in the door.

column2: He was fairly choking with happiness and joy.
column3: He was fairly choking with happiness and joy.

column2: He opened his window, and gazed long, with swelling heart, at the cloudless vault of heaven, and the moon, which shone like silver upon the two-fold stream flowing from far beyond the hills.
column3: He opened his window, and gazed long, with swelling heart, at the cloudless vault of heaven, and the moon, which shone like silver upon the two fold stream flowing from far beyond the hills.

column2: He filled his lungs with the pure, sweet air, while his brain dwelt upon thoughts of happiness, and his heart overflowed with gratitude and religious fervour.
column3: He filled his lungs with the pure, sweet air, while his brain dwelt upon thoughts of happiness, and his heart overflowed with gratitude and religious fervour.

column2: Oh Thou art always watching from on high, my God, he cried, half prostrate, his glowing eyes fixed upon the stars: "forgive me that I almost doubted Thy existence during these latter days, for Thou didst hide Thy face behind the clouds, and wert for a moment lost to my sight, O Thou merciful God, Thou pitying Father everlasting!
column3: Oh Thou art always watching from on high, my God, he cried, half prostrate, his glowing eyes fixed upon the stars: "forgive me that I almost doubted Thy existence during these latter days, for Thou didst hide Thy face behind the clouds, and wert for a moment lost to my sight, O Thou merciful God, Thou pitying Father everlasting!

column2: But to-day, this evening, and to-night, again I see Thee in all Thy wondrous glory in the mirror of Thy heavenly abode, and more clearly still in the mirror of my grateful heart."
column3: But to day, this evening, and to night, again I see Thee in all Thy wondrous glory in the mirror of Thy heavenly abode, and more clearly still in the mirror of my grateful heart."

column2: He was well again, the poor invalid; the wretched captive was free once more.
column3: He was well again, the poor invalid; the wretched captive was free once more.

column2: During part of the night Cornelius, with his heart full of joy and delight, remained at his window, gazing at the stars, and listening for every sound.
column3: During part of the night Cornelius, with his heart full of joy and delight, remained at his window, gazing at the stars, and listening for every sound.

column2: Then casting a glance from time to time towards the lobby,--
column3: Then casting a glance from time to time towards the lobby,--

column2: Down there, he said, "is Rosa, watching like myself, and waiting from minute to minute; down there, under Rosa's eyes, is the mysterious flower, which lives, which expands, which opens, perhaps Rosa holds in this moment the stem of the tulip between her delicate fingers.
column3: Down there, he said, "is Rosa, watching like myself, and waiting from minute to minute; down there, under Rosa's eyes, is the mysterious flower, which lives, which expands, which opens, perhaps Rosa holds in this moment the stem of the tulip between her delicate fingers.

column2: Touch it gently, Rosa.
column3: Touch it gently, Rosa.

column2: Perhaps she touches with her lips its expanding chalice. Touch it cautiously, Rosa, your lips are burning.
column3: Perhaps she touches with her lips its expanding chalice. Touch it cautiously, Rosa, your lips are burning.

column2: Yes, perhaps at this moment the two objects of my dearest love caress each other under the eye of Heaven."
column3: Yes, perhaps at this moment the two objects of my dearest love caress each other under the eye of Heaven."

column2: At this moment, a star blazed in the southern sky, and shot through the whole horizon, falling down, as it were, on the fortress of Loewestein.
column3: At this moment, a star blazed in the southern sky, and shot through the whole horizon, falling down, as it were, on the fortress of Loewestein.

column2: Cornelius felt a thrill run through his frame.
column3: Cornelius felt a thrill run through his frame.

column2: Ah! he said, "here is Heaven sending a soul to my flower."
column3: Ah! he said, "here is Heaven sending a soul to my flower."

column2: And as if he had guessed correctly, nearly at that very moment the prisoner heard in the lobby a step light as that of a sylph, and the rustling of a gown, and a well-known voice, which said to him,--
column3: And as if he had guessed correctly, nearly at that very moment the prisoner heard in the lobby a step light as that of a sylph, and the rustling of a gown, and a well-known voice, which said to him,--

column2: Cornelius, my friend, my very dear friend, and very happy friend, come, come quickly.
column3: Cornelius, my friend, my very dear friend, and very happy friend, come, come quickly.

column2: Cornelius darted with one spring from the window to the door, his lips met those of Rosa, who told him, with a kiss,--
column3: Cornelius darted with one spring from the window to the door, his lips met those of Rosa, who told him, with a kiss,--

column2: It is open, it is black, here it is.
column3: It is open, it is black, here it is.

column2: How! here it is? exclaimed Cornelius.
column3: How! here it is? exclaimed Cornelius.

column2: Yes, yes, we ought indeed to run some little risk to give a great joy; here it is, take it.
column3: Yes, yes, we ought indeed to run some little risk to give a great joy; here it is, take it.

column2: And with one hand she raised to the level of the grating a dark lantern, which she had lit in the meanwhile, whilst with the other she held to the same height the miraculous tulip.
column3: And with one hand she raised to the level of the grating a dark lantern, which she had lit in the meanwhile, whilst with the other she held to the same height the miraculous tulip.

column2: Cornelius uttered a cry, and was nearly fainting.
column3: Cornelius uttered a cry, and was nearly fainting.

column2: Oh! muttered he, "my God, my God, Thou dost reward me for my innocence and my captivity, as Thou hast allowed two such flowers to grow at the grated window of my prison!"
column3: Oh! muttered he, "my God, my God, Thou dost reward me for my innocence and my captivity, as Thou hast allowed two such flowers to grow at the grated window of my prison!"

column2: The tulip was beautiful, splendid, magnificent; its stem was more than eighteen inches high; it rose from out of four green leaves, which were as smooth and straight as iron lance-heads; the whole of the flower was as black and shining as jet.
column3: The tulip was beautiful, splendid, magnificent; its stem was more than eighteen inches high; it rose from out of four green leaves, which were as smooth and straight as iron lance heads; the whole of the flower was as black and shining as jet.

column2: Rosa, said Cornelius, almost gasping, "Rosa, there is not one moment to lose in writing the letter."
column3: Rosa, said Cornelius, almost gasping, "Rosa, there is not one moment to lose in writing the letter."

column2: It is written, my dearest Cornelius, said Rosa.
column3: It is written, my dearest Cornelius, said Rosa.

column2: Is it, indeed?
column3: Is it, indeed?

column2: Whilst the tulip opened I wrote it myself, for I did not wish to lose a moment.	Whilst the tulip opened I wrote it myself, for I did not wish to lose a moment.
column3: true

column2: Here is the letter, and tell me whether you approve of it."
column3: Here is the letter, and tell me whether you approve of it."

column2: Cornelius took the letter, and read, in a handwriting which was much improved even since the last little note he had received from Rosa, as follows:--
column3: Cornelius took the letter, and read, in a handwriting which was much improved even since the last little note he had received from Rosa, as follows:--

column2: Mynheer President,--The black tulip is about to open, perhaps in ten minutes.	Mynheer President,--The black tulip is about to open, perhaps in ten minutes.
column3: true

column2: As soon as it is open, I shall send a messenger to you, with the request that you will come and fetch it in person from the fortress at Loewestein.
column3: As soon as it is open, I shall send a messenger to you, with the request that you will come and fetch it in person from the fortress at Loewestein.

column2: I am the daughter of the jailer, Gryphus, almost as much of a captive as the prisoners of my father.
column3: I am the daughter of the jailer, Gryphus, almost as much of a captive as the prisoners of my father.

column2: I cannot, therefore, bring to you this wonderful flower.
column3: I cannot, therefore, bring to you this wonderful flower.

column2: This is the reason why I beg you to come and fetch it yourself.
column3: This is the reason why I beg you to come and fetch it yourself.

column2: It is my wish that it should be called Rosa Barlaensis.	It is my wish that it should be called Rosa Barlaensis.
column3: true

column2: It has opened; it is perfectly black; come, Mynheer President, come.	It has opened; it is perfectly black; come, Mynheer President, come.
column3: false

column2: I have the honour to be your humble servant,	I have the honour to be your humble servant,
column3: true

column2: Rosa Gryphus.	Rosa Gryphus.
column3: true

column2: That's it, dear Rosa, that's it.	That's it, dear Rosa, that's it.
column3: true

column2: Your letter is admirable!
column3: Your letter is admirable!

column2: I could not have written it with such beautiful simplicity.
column3: I could not have written it with such beautiful simplicity.

column2: You will give to the committee all the information that will be required of you.
column3: You will give to the committee all the information that will be required of you.

column2: They will then know how the tulip has been grown, how much care and anxiety, and how many sleepless nights, it has cost.
column3: They will then know how the tulip has been grown, how much care and anxiety, and how many sleepless nights, it has cost.

column2: But for the present not a minute must be lost.
column3: But for the present not a minute must be lost.

column2: The messenger! the messenger!"
column3: The messenger! the messenger!"

column2: What's the name of the President?
column3: What's the name of the President?

column2: Give me the letter, I will direct it.	Give me the letter, I will direct it.
column3: true

column2: Oh, he is very well known: it is Mynheer van Systens, the burgomaster of Haarlem; give it to me, Rosa, give it to me."
column3: Oh, he is very well known: it is Mynheer van Systens, the burgomaster of Haarlem; give it to me, Rosa, give it to me."

column2: And with a trembling hand Cornelius wrote the address,--
column3: And with a trembling hand Cornelius wrote the address,--

column2: To Mynheer Peter van Systens, Burgomaster, and President of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem.
column3: To Mynheer peter van Systens, Burgomaster, and President of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem.

column2: And now, Rosa, go, go, said Cornelius, "and let us implore the protection of God, who has so kindly watched over us until now."
column3: And now, Rosa, go, go, said Cornelius, "and let us implore the protection of God, who has so kindly watched over us until now."
